title: Do people prefer this over what League used to be ?
body:
The insane damage you do at 15 minutes into the match, most damage champions only require 1 item to start popping off and deal insane damage.

Now i'm talking about the normal and lower ranks, riot only cares and builds the game around the E'sport scene while the actual majority of the games  turn into fiestas. 

I've played this game on-off since Season 1 and i've never had as little fun as now. The old nostalgia games where actual teamwork and thinking mattered are gone,when you got into champ select and people talked team comps and synergy. Now people rather go for high damage champions & play solo, build 1-2 items and start death matching and chasing each other for 20-30 minutes until 1 team wins. Its boring, and that's why more than half of the champion pool isn't played, because the only viable thing to do in this game unless you're high mmr or in the pro scene is to buy damage and play solo. 


Just my thoughts.

Man I miss the old League... games were long enough that Teamplay and Strategy was the win-con, but not so long that it was just a 5v5 6 item clash in mid lane. People hate on Tank meta but that was one of the most balanced metas for teamwork and map control because teamfights weren't over in 1/20th of a second so you needed to fight over objectives to not fall behind. Although it could just be that Tank Meta came in after a much deserved buff to tanks and nerf to ADC's who were completely unstoppable (assassins were garbage and continued to be garbage through Tank meta except for those who could build tank... which eventually led to the death of Tank meta). 

I see people all the time "hurr durr I have so many 40 minutes games you all dumb" yea i have a lot of games that go longer than 30 minutes, but the game is over at 10 minutes... the remaining time is the winning team ending the game. When I say I want 45 minute games, I want the game to be decided at 35-40 minutes and then the remaining 5-10 minutes is the game closing out, like how it used to be.  

This was the best for both teams! It was less frustrating to lose because it wasn't dragged out over 30+ minutes with the score 54-12 and more satisfying to win because you had to constantly outplay and out-maneuver.  

But it makes sense that Riot is making the game the way it is right now. Their largest playerbase is now in China, they are losing the rest of their playerbase and have been for awhile, so they are catering the game to them right now. The Chinese want their games to be shorter due to them not having personal computers and they play in internet cafe's and such where they have to pay for a certain amount of time. Shorter games = more games.   

Games die, it happens. I really think Riot chose the wrong player-base to balance towards. Its not that I don't care about the Chinese playerbase and I think its fair to want to make the game more accessible for them, but it has gone too far and I think there won't be any chance at recovering at this point.

When are people going to stop saying this.

No, Riot does not "only care about the esports scene" and it's been proven time and again by their balance decisions:

* Riot balances predominantly around ranks that are nowhere near pro-level (High plat/low diamond)
* Riot frequently has patches that hit champs only good in solo/low queue (Bye Yorick)
* RIot will occasionally do a pro-centric patch. Usually around worlds.
* Balance has always favored lower-tier players more than higher tier players.
* Balance decisions are often about placebo buffs/nerfs more than things that have lasting impact in pro/high tier games.

People don't want to swallow the pill but Riot balances around casual play. Perhaps way more than they actually should. As a lasting reminder: Everything currently happening with the game could be traced back to Dunkey's "I'm quitting League" video in which all the things people say they missed (long games, extremely low damage, games only decided by late game teamfights and nothing else) were hardcore complaints back in the day.

If Riot actually balanced around pros to the degree boards says they do, we'd see a LOT more interesting pro games than the handicapped balancing we have today.

I do not share your opinion. There were so much more point and click spells and stats-checkers champions back then.

The game was a lot of fun in the early days, but it's not necessarily because it was balanced - it was just broken in ways that felt fairer and less punishing to play.  Early seasons had some *insane* damage.  But it was mostly on scalings.  There were however also some insanely broken items.  Most people forget that Season 1 was dominated by mages, because something called Zhonya's Ring existed in the game - it was literally {{item:3089}} {{item:3157}} in one item, for the cost of one item.    What didn't exist as much in the early seasons were the depth of champion selections, strategies, and knowledge that exist today, the amount of front-loaded *physical* damage {{item:3078}} {{item:3095}} {{item:3147}} represent,   the damage/mobility creep represented by the past several seasons' worth of reworks, and the war on mana.

For me, even with the balance issues that existed, early seasons felt better because:
- the old rune system gave a lot more flexibility on builds and stats than Runes Reforged
- mana-based champions weren't constantly forced to recall because of forced mana shortages
- when you got one-shotted it was usually by a spell or ability that you knew you shouldn't be getting hit by - instead of two or three near-instant autoattacks and/or spammable physical abilities

Others' experience may vary.   

I think that it's entirely possible that "Runes Reforged" should actually just become Masteries Reforged - and possibly see certain nerfs to reduce keystones to the level of old masteries -  and that the old runes and stat bonuses should come back but be free.  I think the new system has produced some new and cool iconic abilities - Klepto, Grasp, Augment are the kinds of things I think are not fundamentally broken and deserve to stay - but the ability to customize your early free ~1000 gold worth of stats so precisely was more empowering.
